sect1.title: OBS Appliances
sect1.para: This chapter gives an overview over the different OBS appliances and how to deploy them for production use.

sect2.title: Server Appliance
sect2.para: The &obsa; server appliance contains a recent &opensuse; distribution with a pre-installed and pre-configured OBS front-end, back-end and worker. The operating system on this appliance adapts to the hardware on first boot and defaults to automatic IP and DNS configuration via DHCP.

sect2.title: Worker Appliance
sect2.para: The &obsa; worker appliance includes a recent &opensuse; distribution and the &obsa; worker component. The operating system on this appliance adapts to the hardware on first boot, defaults to automatic IP and DNS configuration via DHCP and &obsa; server discovery via SLP.

sect2.title: Image Types
sect2.para: There are different types of &obsa; appliance images.

note.para: Our VirtualBox images are usually better tested.

sect2.title: Deployment
sect2.para: To help you deploy the OBS server appliance to a hard disk there is a basic installer that you can boot from a USB stick. The installer can be found on the OBS Download page.
The image can be written to a USB stick to boot from it:

warning.para: /dev/sdX is the main device of your USB stick. Do NOT put it into a partition like /dev/sda1. If you use the wrong device, you will destroy all data on it!

sect2.para: How to deploy the other image types deeply depends on your virtualization setup. Describing this is out of scope for this guide, sorry.

sect2.title: Separating Data from the System
sect2.para: For production use you want to separate the OBS data from operating system of the appliance so you can re-deploy the appliance without touching your OBS data. This can be achieved by creating an LVM volume group with the name "OBS". This volume group should be as large as possible because it is getting used by the OBS back-end for data storage and the OBS workers for root/swap/cache file systems. Additionally, if the OBS volume group contains a logical volume named server, it will be used as the data partition for the server.

sect2.title: Updating the Appliance
sect2.para: All images come pre-configured with the right set of repositories and can be updated via the system tools YaST or zypper at any time. Another way to update is to re-deploy the entire image.

warning.para: If you re-deploy the entire image, keep in mind that you need to have your data directory (/srv/obs) on a separate storage (LVM volume, partition etc.) otherwise it will be deleted!
